stream_context.summary: Kaze codes and tests multiple elements for Return to Yoshi’s Island, focusing on an oil-themed factory area in Course 2: new "seesaw" set-piece that squashes a Goomba, updated tox boxes, collision and performance tweaks, plus early design of a construction-worker Womp. He also demos the gigantic “Only Up 64” competition level and stress-tests everything on real N64 hardware.
level: Course 2 – Oily Boily Bay / Bowser Fleet Factory

development_findings.summary: Created higher-resolution tox boxes; still needs a method to keep Mario from clipping through their walls.
Implemented new collision routines that greatly stabilise head-bonk and ceiling behaviour.
development_findings.quote: You guys probably can’t really tell the difference but it’s very noticeable when you’re walking into ceilings like this – it’s a lot more stable now.

development_findings.summary: Designed and partially coded a seesaw plank with a Goomba at one end and a breakable box at the other; smashing the box tips the plank and squashes the Goomba.
development_findings.quote: I want the player to be able to stop it from falling while Mario is still on there…and then it slowly squish him down.

development_findings.summary: Seesaw motion is an authored animation, not real physics, to stay within console limits; bounce and speed values tuned during stream.
Performance on N64 improved from ~19 FPS to ~25 FPS by enabling back-face culling on metal materials and pruning unseen triangles.
development_findings.quote: Backface culling is insane – that was the entire performance difference.

development_findings.summary: Level polycount currently ~6k (geometry) / 13k (with text); further gains planned via collision maps and deleting underside faces.
Testing revealed a division-by-zero crash; root cause was compiler reordering the divide into a delay slot. Fixed by separating the calculations.
development_findings.quote: That’s not a bug in the code – the compiler pipelined the division so I always divide by zero.

development_findings.summary: Added system so only specific areas use the new clip ratio to reduce lag on N64.
Game requires Expansion Pak; fitting into 4 MB would need per-area loading and isn’t worth the effort right now.
Five footstep sound slots remain; considering new material sounds like glass.
Debated design of transparent (collected) stars and red-coin spawn markers; wants clear player signalling.
Initial design for a construction-worker Womp: carries steel beam, helmet strapped to back (vulnerable spot), tipped by a kick.
Zeina has finished animations for “cement pit guy” enemy; still missing animations for the “glass curry” and Overseer boss.
Music for this area undecided; Badub was expected to compose but has been absent.
Only Up 64 level ~60 % complete; target 25-minute vertical climb; N64 compatibility untested yet.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is juggling stream work, Only Up 64, a tech-conference presentation, and his day job, leaving him feeling overloaded.
context_findings.quote: Man I’m so busy actually – I will never have my freedom.

context_findings.summary: YouTube revenue is low; Brilliant sponsorship ended; channel is only barely profitable.
context_findings.quote: My YouTube channel is barely profitable, especially now that Brilliant doesn’t sponsor me anymore.

context_findings.summary: He avoids streaming on main channel to protect algorithm and prefers smaller engaged audience focused on game development.
context_findings.quote: I just care about making a good game. My streams here – if you get entertained that’s a side effect.

context_findings.summary: Expresses coding philosophy: prefers minimal comments, believing clean code is better documentation.
context_findings.quote: The code itself is better documentation than your documentation so you should remove your documentation.

context_findings.summary: Frustration with YouTube latency and with Parallel Launcher; relies on Project64 for reliable tests.
Heatwave during stream; occasional humour about dying from heat.
Won’t disclose exact salary out of respect for employer; works for Danish company with remote colleagues.

biobak.summary: Provided feedback on textures, performance, and trailer submissions for F3; active in chat.

badub.summary: Expected to compose new track but has been absent from recent sessions, leaving music undecided.

zeina.summary: Delivered animations for the “cement pit guy”; not present in stream because out with friends.

key_stories.title: Seesaw Goomba Set-Piece
key_stories.summary: Kaze prototypes a plank with a Goomba on one end and a breakable box on the other. After multiple tweaks to speed, bounce, and collision, the plank convincingly tips forward and pins the Goomba.
key_stories.challenge: Create an interactive environmental gag that feels physical yet runs on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Scripted the motion as ‘fake physics’, adjusted angular velocity, added conditionals to stop Mario being carried through walls, and iterated live on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Stable, comedic sequence ready for polish (sound effect, final Goomba behaviour).
key_stories.key_quote: That ending pose is beautiful – I love this.

key_stories.title: FPS Rescue via Back-Face Culling
key_stories.summary: Factory level dipped to 19 FPS when looking across geometry. By enabling back-face culling on metal materials and trimming unseen faces, performance rose to 25 FPS without noticeable visual loss on hardware.
key_stories.challenge: Maintain acceptable framerate in the project’s largest, most detailed area.
key_stories.process: Profiled triangle counts, toggled material flags, compiled for N64, measured FPS, and compared emulator visuals.
key_stories.outcome: Console-specific culling will ship; further collision-map and triangle pruning planned.
key_stories.key_quote: I predicted 25 and we hit 25 – backface culling is insane.

key_stories.title: Compiler Betrayal Crash
key_stories.summary: An N64 crash led to discovery that the GCC toolchain had rearranged a divide instruction into a branch delay slot, forcing a divide-by-zero.
key_stories.challenge: Random floating-point exception during console boot.
key_stories.process: Read disassembly, identified pipelined divide, moved calculations out of delay slot and recompiled in two repos.
key_stories.outcome: Build boots reliably; same fix ported to Only Up 64 codebase.
key_stories.key_quote: This isn’t my bug – the compiler unconditionally pipelined the division.

open_questions.context: Kaze has five ‘workers’ (e.g., Goomba on seesaw, construction Womp) to mess with but hasn’t decided how players learn these interactions.
questions: What teaching methods or visual cues will show players they can sabotage each worker?
Will there be a common mechanic across all five or unique hints per enemy?
How does this fit into overall mission structure and star objectives?

open_questions.context: Badub was expected to compose the area’s theme but has been absent; no replacement plan discussed.
questions: Has Badub started any tracks for Oily Boily Bay?
Is there a contingency composer if schedules don’t align?
What musical direction (genre, instrumentation) suits the factory theme?

open_questions.context: Zeina finished cement pit guy but glass curry and Overseer animations are pending.
questions: What is the animation scope for these characters?
Are there technical constraints Zeina must consider?
How does timeline align with planned demo or release?

open_questions.context: Level is 60 % done and untested on hardware; Kaze hopes it will run on console.
questions: What is the current polygon budget and performance expectation?
What fallback plans exist if hardware can’t handle it?
Will learnings from RtYI optimisations transfer to Only Up 64?

open_questions.context: Kaze refuses to predict release dates and has no visible plan.
questions: What internal milestones exist for Return to Yoshi’s Island?
Is a demo or episodic release considered?
How will legal risks with Nintendo be mitigated?
